elements.content: A metastable three-dimensional cadmium­(II) coordination polymer with (2-carboxyethyl)­(phenyl)­phosphinate (L2–) and 4,4′-bipyridine (bipy) as ligands, namely, [Cd­(L)­(bipy)­(H2O)2] (1), can be converted to two new two-dimensional/three-dimensional varieties under hydrothermal treatments at different temperatures, that is, [Cd­(L)­(bipy)] (2) and [Cd­(L)­(bipy)0.5]·0.5H2O (3). Their syntheses, crystal structures, structural transformations, and luminescent properties are presented. In addition, 1 shows a second harmonic generation response that is ∼0.3 times that of KDP (KH2PO4).

Their syntheses, crystal structures, structural transformations, and luminescent properties are presented. In addition, 1 shows a second harmonic generation response that is ~0.3 times that of KDP (KH2PO4).

elements.content: Crystal structural transformation of coordination polymers, as a very fascinating phenomenon in crystal engineering, has received considerable interest because it would open opportunities to gain better understanding of the fundamental factors that influence the crystal self-assembly process and hence help to develop functional materials. In general, the synthesis of coordination polymers is carried out in solution, and the transformation of a crystallized coordination polymer through disassembly and reassembly often involves the rearrangement of its molecular components, including rotation, bending, swinging, sliding, shrinking, or swelling, which may be triggered by guest removal/inclusion, ligand substitution, expansion of coordination numbers, and/or a more compact packing of the overall crystal structure.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Crystal structural transformation of coordination polymers, as a very fascinating phenomenon in crystal engineering, has received considerable interest because it would open opportunities to gain better understanding of the fundamental factors that influence the crystal self-assembly process and hence help to develop functional materials. In general, the synthesis of coordination polymers is carried out in solution, and the transformation of a crystallized coordination polymer through disassembly and reassembly often involves the rearrangement of its molecular components, including rotation, bending, swinging, sliding, shrinking, or swelling, which may be triggered by guest removal/inclusion, ligand substitution, expansion of coordination numbers, and/or a more compact packing of the overall crystal structure.

elements.content: Recently, we have undertaken research work on the coordination and supramolecular chemistry of an asymmetric bifunctional ligand, (2-carboxyethyl)­(phenyl)­phosphinic acid (H2L). Such a ligand features two formally analogous carboxylate and phosphinate moieties (i.e., both feature two potentinal O donors) separated by a flexible −CH2CH2– spacer, with the latter being further bonded to a phenyl group. In the present work, we initially isolated a three-dimensional (3D) cadmium­(II) carboxylate-phosphinate with 4,4′-bipyridine (bipy) as a coligand, namely, [Cd­(L)­(bipy)­(H2O)2] (1), which crystallizes in the polar space group Cc. The coordinative unsaturation of the L2– ligand in 1 provides a hint that such a complex may be metastable, and our subsequent studies revealed that 1 can be converted to two new two-dimensional (2D)/3D varieties under hydrothermal treatments at different temperatures; that is, the removal of its two aqua ligands and the further loss of its half bipy ligands led to [Cd­(L)­(bipy)] (2) and [Cd­(L)­(bipy)0.5]·0.5H2O (3), respectively. Herein, we report the interesting temperature-dependent crystal self-assembly, disassembly, and reassembly among them.

Such a ligand features two formally analogous carboxylate and phosphinate moieties (i.e., both feature two potentinal O donors) separated by a flexible -CH2CH2- spacer, with the latter being further bonded to a phenyl group. In the present work, we initially isolated a three-dimensional (3D) cadmium(II) carboxylate-phosphinate with 4,4'-bipyridine (bipy) as a coligand, namely, [Cd(L)(bipy)(H2O)2] (1), which crystallizes in the polar space group Cc. The coordinative unsaturation of the L2- ligand in 1 provides a hint that such a complex may be metastable, and our subsequent studies revealed that 1 can be converted to two new two-dimensional (2D)/3D varieties under hydrothermal treatments at different temperatures; that is, the removal of its two aqua ligands and the further loss of its half bipy ligands led to [Cd(L)(bipy)] (2) and [Cd(L)(bipy)0.5]⋅0.5H2O (3), respectively. Herein, we report the interesting temperature-dependent crystal self-assembly, disassembly, and reassembly among them.

elements.content: 2-Carboxyethyl­(phenyl)­phosphinic acid was synthesized using a published procedure. All other chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on a German Elementary Vario EL III instrument. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured on a Rigaku MiniFlex II using Cu–Kα radiation. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 2000 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on a Diamond TG/DTA 6000 unit at a heating rate of 15 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. Photoluminescence analysis was performed on a Perkin Elemer LS55 fluorescence spectrometer. The measurements of the powder frequency-doubling effects were carried out by means of the method of Kurtz and Perry. A 1064 nm radiation generated by a Q-switched Nd: YAG solid-state laser was used as the fundamental frequency light. The crystal sample was ground and sieved into particle sizes in the range of 150–210 μm. The sieved sample was packed in round glass boxes with a uniform diameter of 8.0 mm and then exposed to laser radiations. Second harmonic radiation generated by the randomly oriented microcrystals was detected by a photomultiplier tube and displayed on an oscilloscope. Sample of KDP in the same particle sizes was prepared as reference material in an identical fashion to assume the second harmonic generation (SHG) effect.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

2-Carboxyethyl(phenyl)phosphinic acid was synthesized using a published procedure. All other chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on a German Elementary Vario EL III instrument. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured on a Rigaku MiniFlex II using Cu-Kα radiation. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 2000 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on a Diamond TG/DTA 6000 unit at a heating rate of 15 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. Photoluminescence analysis was performed on a Perkin Elemer LS55 fluorescence spectrometer. The measurements of the powder frequency-doubling effects were carried out by means of the method of Kurtz and Perry. A 1064 nm radiation generated by a Q-switched Nd: YAG solid-state laser was used as the fundamental frequency light. The crystal sample was ground and sieved into particle sizes in the range of 150-210 μm. The sieved sample was packed in round glass boxes with a uniform diameter of 8.0 mm and then exposed to laser radiations. Second harmonic radiation generated by the randomly oriented microcrystals was detected by a photomultiplier tube and displayed on an oscilloscope. Sample of KDP in the same particle sizes was prepared as reference material in an identical fashion to assume the second harmonic generation (SHG) effect.

elements.content: Data collections for 1–3 were performed on a Smart ApexII CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at a temperature of 296 K. The data sets were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors as well as for absorption by SADABS program. All structures were solved by the direct method using SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. All hydrogen atoms except those of the water molecules were generated geometrically and refined isotropically. Hydrogen atoms of the water molecules in 1 were located in the difference Fourier map and refined with U iso(H) values set at 1.5U eq(O), while those in 3 are not included in the refinements. The occupancy factor of the lattice water molecule O­(1W) in 3 was reduced to 50% because of its larger thermal parameter. Crystallographic data and structural refinements for 1–3 are summarized in Table . Important bond lengths are listed in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination for 1-3 

Data collections for 1-3 were performed on a Smart ApexII CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at a temperature of 296 K. The data sets were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors as well as for absorption by SADABS program. All structures were solved by the direct method using SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. All hydrogen atoms except those of the water molecules were generated geometrically and refined isotropically. Hydrogen atoms of the water molecules in 1 were located in the difference Fourier map and refined with U iso(H) values set at 1.5U eq(O), while those in 3 are not included in the refinements. The occupancy factor of the lattice water molecule O(1W) in 3 was reduced to 50% because of its larger thermal parameter. Crystallographic data and structural refinements for 1-3 are summarized in Table . Important bond lengths are listed in Table .

Compound 1 crystallizes in the non-centrosymmetric space group Cc and it exhibits a 3D framework. The asymmetric unit contains one Cd2+ ion, one L2– anion, and one bipy ligand as well as two aqua ligands. The Cd(1) center is octahedrally coordinated by one phosphinate O atom and one carboxylate O atom from two L2– ligands, two N donors of two bipy ligands, and two aqua ligands (Figure ). The L2– ligand bridges two Cd2+ ions via one phosphinate O atom and one carboxylate O atom (Scheme a), while the bipy ligand also serves as a bidentate bridging ligand. The interconnection of the Cd2+ centers by the above two ligands leads to two types of chains along the c- and b-axes, respectively, and the cross-linking of such two kinds of chains results in a complicated 3D framework (Figure a). From a topological point of view, the Cd2+ centers can be simplified as four-connected nodes, while the bidentate bridging L2– and bipy ligands both are defined as linkers; then the 3D framework of 1 can be described as a 4-connected cds topology (Figure b), which is somehow similar to that of CdSO4. It is also worthy of note that the [Cd­(L)] chains in 1 are arranged in a uni-oriented “↑↑↑↑······” fashion (Chart a), which results its crystallization in the polar space group Cc.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of Structure 1 

Compound 1 crystallizes in the non-centrosymmetric space group Cc and it exhibits a 3D framework. The asymmetric unit contains one Cd2+ ion, one L2- anion, and one bipy ligand as well as two aqua ligands. The Cd(1) center is octahedrally coordinated by one phosphinate O atom and one carboxylate O atom from two L2- ligands, two N donors of two bipy ligands, and two aqua ligands (Figure ). The L2- ligand bridges two Cd2+ ions via one phosphinate O atom and one carboxylate O atom (Scheme a), while the bipy ligand also serves as a bidentate bridging ligand. The interconnection of the Cd2+ centers by the above two ligands leads to two types of chains along the c- and b-axes, respectively, and the cross-linking of such two kinds of chains results in a complicated 3D framework (Figure a). From a topological point of view, the Cd2+ centers can be simplified as four-connected nodes, while the bidentate bridging L2- and bipy ligands both are defined as linkers; then the 3D framework of 1 can be described as a 4-connected cds topology (Figure b), which is somehow similar to that of CdSO4. It is also worthy of note that the [Cd(L)] chains in 1 are arranged in a uni-oriented "↑↑↑↑⋅⋅⋅⋅⋅⋅" fashion (Chart a), which results its crystallization in the polar space group Cc.

Description of Structure <bold>2</bold>

Compound 2 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric space group P21/c and it features a 2D layer structure. The asymmetric unit contains one Cd2+ ion, one L2– anion, and one bipy ligand. The Cd(1) center adopts a distorted square pyramid geometry and is five-coordinate with two phosphinate O atoms and two carboxylate O atoms from four L2– ligands as well as one N donor of a bipy ligand (Figure ). The L2– ligand bridges four Cd2+ ions via two phosphinate O atoms and two carboxylate O atoms (Scheme b), whereas the bipy ligand here is only monodentate. The interconnection of the Cd2+ ions by the bridging L2– ligands results in the formation of a corrugated layer structure (Chart b), which features three types of dimeric ring motifs (rings B , C , and D , see Scheme ). From the topological perspective, both of the Cd2+ centers and L2– ligands can be defined as four-connected nodes, and the interconnection of the two kinds of nodes in a 1:1 ratio gives a 2D (4,4) net (Figure b).

Description of Structure 2 

Compound 2 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric space group P21/c and it features a 2D layer structure. The asymmetric unit contains one Cd2+ ion, one L2- anion, and one bipy ligand. The Cd(1) center adopts a distorted square pyramid geometry and is five-coordinate with two phosphinate O atoms and two carboxylate O atoms from four L2- ligands as well as one N donor of a bipy ligand (Figure ). The L2- ligand bridges four Cd2+ ions via two phosphinate O atoms and two carboxylate O atoms (Scheme b), whereas the bipy ligand here is only monodentate. The interconnection of the Cd2+ ions by the bridging L2- ligands results in the formation of a corrugated layer structure (Chart b), which features three types of dimeric ring motifs (rings  B ,  C , and  D , see Scheme ). From the topological perspective, both of the Cd2+ centers and L2- ligands can be defined as four-connected nodes, and the interconnection of the two kinds of nodes in a 1:1 ratio gives a 2D (4,4) net (Figure b).

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric space group C2/c, and it exhibits another type of 3D framework. The asymmetric unit contains two halves Cd2+ ion, one L2– anion, and half bipy ligand as well as half lattice water molecule. The Cd(1) and Cd(2) centers both lie on a crystallographic 2-fold axis parallel to the b-axis, with the former being octahedrally coordinated by two phosphinate O atoms and two carboxylate O atoms of two pairs of symmetry-related L2– ligands as well as two N donors from two symmetry-related bipy ligands, while the latter is octahedrally coordinated by two phosphinate O atoms and two bidentate chelating carboxylate groups from two pairs of symmetry-related L2– ligands (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
Description of Structure 3 

Compound 3 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric space group C2/c, and it exhibits another type of 3D framework. The asymmetric unit contains two halves Cd2+ ion, one L2- anion, and half bipy ligand as well as half lattice water molecule. The Cd(1) and Cd(2) centers both lie on a crystallographic 2-fold axis parallel to the b-axis, with the former being octahedrally coordinated by two phosphinate O atoms and two carboxylate O atoms of two pairs of symmetry-related L2- ligands as well as two N donors from two symmetry-related bipy ligands, while the latter is octahedrally coordinated by two phosphinate O atoms and two bidentate chelating carboxylate groups from two pairs of symmetry-related L2- ligands (Figure ).

elements.content: The L2– ligand bridges two Cd(1) and two Cd(2) ions via two monodentate phosphinate O atoms, one monodentate carboxylate O atom, and one bidentate carboxylate O atom (Scheme c), whereas the bipy ligand links two Cd(1) ions via two N donors. The interconnection of the Cd2+ centers by the bridging L2– and bipy ligands results in the formation of a 3D framework (Figure a). Such 3D structure can be viewed as a pillar-layered architecture, in which [Cd­(L)] layers along the bc-plane are further cross-linked by the bipy ligands. The [Cd­(L)] layer contains four types of dimeric ring motifs (rings A , B , D , and E ; see Scheme ), among which the two small rings A and B both feature a 2-fold symmetry, while the two big rings D and E both are centrosymmetric. From a topological viewpoint, the doubly μ2-O-linked dimeric unit (Cd(1)­Cd(2)­O2, see ring A ) and the L2– ligand can be reduced as eight- and three-connected nodes, respectively, while the bidentate bridging bipy ligands are defined as linkers; thus, the 3D framework of 3 can be identified as a (3,8) net (Figure b).

The interconnection of the Cd2+ centers by the bridging L2- and bipy ligands results in the formation of a 3D framework (Figure a). Such 3D structure can be viewed as a pillar-layered architecture, in which [Cd(L)] layers along the bc-plane are further cross-linked by the bipy ligands. The [Cd(L)] layer contains four types of dimeric ring motifs (rings  A ,  B ,  D , and  E ; see Scheme ), among which the two small rings  A  and  B  both feature a 2-fold symmetry, while the two big rings  D  and  E  both are centrosymmetric. From a topological viewpoint, the doubly μ2-O-linked dimeric unit (Cd(1)Cd(2)O2, see ring  A ) and the L2- ligand can be reduced as eight- and three-connected nodes, respectively, while the bidentate bridging bipy ligands are defined as linkers; thus, the 3D framework of 3 can be identified as a (3,8) net (Figure b).

elements.content: The disassembly of the aqua and bipy ligands occurred under hydrothermal treatment of crystals of 1 with their mother liquor, and the exposed Cd2+ sites can be compensated by the coordinatively unsaturated L2– ligand, leading to the reassembly of two new 2D/3D varieties, namely, 2 and 3.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structural Transformations

The disassembly of the aqua and bipy ligands occurred under hydrothermal treatment of crystals of 1 with their mother liquor, and the exposed Cd2+ sites can be compensated by the coordinatively unsaturated L2- ligand, leading to the reassembly of two new 2D/3D varieties, namely, 2 and 3.

elements.content: The [Cd­(L)] layer in 2 can be evolved from the [Cd­(L)] chains in 1. As shown in Chart , the O–Cd–O angles in the [Cd­(L)] chains of 1 are adjusted significantly to match the subsequent arrangement changing from a uni-oriented “↑↑↑↑······” mode to a centrosymmetric “↑↓↓↑↑↓······” fashion, with a much shorter chain interval (distance between four adjacent [Cd­(L)] chains: 16.9647(4) → 11.1480(2) Å); then the further interlinking of these chains leads to a [Cd­(L)] layer of 2 (Chart b). The final layer structure of 2 is completed by the coordination of a mondentate bipy ligand to each Cd2+ center, which acts as a terminal ligand (Figure a). It is worthy to note that the overall 3D → 2D transformation increases the symmetry accompanied by a more compact stacking in the crystal (D calcd: 1.677 → 1.744 g·cm–3).
elements.clean_text: The [Cd(L)] layer in 2 can be evolved from the [Cd(L)] chains in 1. As shown in Chart , the O-Cd-O angles in the [Cd(L)] chains of 1 are adjusted significantly to match the subsequent arrangement changing from a uni-oriented "↑↑↑↑⋅⋅⋅⋅⋅⋅" mode to a centrosymmetric "↑↓↓↑↑↓⋅⋅⋅⋅⋅⋅" fashion, with a much shorter chain interval (distance between four adjacent [Cd(L)] chains: 16.9647(4) → 11.1480(2) Å); then the further interlinking of these chains leads to a [Cd(L)] layer of 2 (Chart b). The final layer structure of 2 is completed by the coordination of a mondentate bipy ligand to each Cd2+ center, which acts as a terminal ligand (Figure a). It is worthy to note that the overall 3D → 2D transformation increases the symmetry accompanied by a more compact stacking in the crystal (D calcd: 1.677 → 1.744 g⋅cm-3).

elements.content: The [Cd­(L)] layer in 3 also can be converted from the [Cd­(L)] chains in 1. As shown in Chart , the [Cd­(L)] chains of 1 are transformed into two types of [Cd­(L)] chains of 3: one shows a slight change of the O–Cd–O angle, while the other features a bidentate chelating carboxylate group altering from the previous monodentate mode. These chains are arranged in a “↑i↓ii↑i↓ii······” fashion, with a shorter chain interval (distance between four adjacent [Cd­(L)] chains: 16.9647(4) → 13.4318(3) Å), and then the further interlinking of these chains leads to a [Cd­(L)] layer structure of 3 (Chart c). The [Cd­(L)] layers are finally built to a pillar-layered framework via the bridging of the bipy ligands at Cd(1) centers. It is also worthy to note that the overall 3D → 3D transformation increases the symmetry accompanied by a more compact stacking in the crystal (D calcd: 1.677 → 1.787 g·cm–3).

elements.content: The solid-state luminescent spectra of 1–3 were investigated at room temperature (Figure ). The free 2-carboxyethyl­(phenyl)­phosphinate ligand shows only a fluorescent emission band at λmax = 293 nm under 225 nm excitation. The 4,4′-bipyridine ligand displays a broad fluorescent emission band at λmax = 423 nm upon excitation at 345 nm. Upon complexion of the L2– ligand and 4,4′-bipyridine ligand with the Cd2+ ions, complex 1 displays a fluorescent emission band at λmax = 429 nm (λex = 379 nm), and compound 2 displays a fluorescent emission band at λmax = 369, 388 nm (λex = 336 nm), while compound 3 displays a fluorescent emission band at λmax = 379 nm (λex= 283 nm). These emission bands are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) in nature, but rather can be attributed to an intraligand (IL) and ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT) emission state, which is similar to our previously reported zinc­(II) phosphonate with bipy as a coligand.

Optical Properties

elements.content: TGA curves of 1 and 3 both exhibit three main steps of weight losses, while that of 2 features two main steps of weight losses (Figure ). For 1 and 3, the first steps of weight loss correspond to the release of 2 and 0.5 H2O, respectively. The observed weight loss for 1 (7.2%) is close to the calculated value (7.0%), which starts at 90 °C and is complete at 156 °C, and the observed weight loss for 3 (2.2%) is equal to the calculated value (2.2%), which starts at 40 °C and is complete at 95 °C. The subsequent weight losses of 1 and 3 start at 172 and 273 °C, respectively, corresponding to the decomposition of the organic ligands. TGA curve of 2 shows that it is stable up to 167 °C, whereupon the decomposition of the organic ligand occurs. By and large, we can deduce that the framework of 3 is more stable than those of 1 and 2.

elements.content: In summary, we have found a unique example of a 3D metastable coordination polymer ([Cd­(L)­(bipy)­(H2O)2] (1)) that can be converted to two new 2D/3D varieties ([Cd­(L)­(bipy)] (2) and [Cd­(L)­(bipy)0.5]·0.5H2O (3)) under hydrothermal treatments at different temperatures. The transformations are related to the disassembly and reassembly of the crystals. The removal of two aqua ligands and the further loss of half 4,4′-bipyridine ligands in 1 triggered the collective reorientation of the [Cd­(L)] chains in 1 and the subsequent formation of two compact [Cd­(L)] layers in 2 and 3, with the exposed Cd2+ sites being compensated by the coordinatively unsaturated L2– ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have found a unique example of a 3D metastable coordination polymer ([Cd(L)(bipy)(H2O)2] (1)) that can be converted to two new 2D/3D varieties ([Cd(L)(bipy)] (2) and [Cd(L)(bipy)0.5]⋅0.5H2O (3)) under hydrothermal treatments at different temperatures. The transformations are related to the disassembly and reassembly of the crystals. The removal of two aqua ligands and the further loss of half 4,4'-bipyridine ligands in 1 triggered the collective reorientation of the [Cd(L)] chains in 1 and the subsequent formation of two compact [Cd(L)] layers in 2 and 3, with the exposed Cd2+ sites being compensated by the coordinatively unsaturated L2- ligand.

Synthesis of [Cd­(L)­(bipy)] (<bold>2</bold>)

When the above as-synthesized crystals of 1 with their mother liquor were sealed into a Parr Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated at 120 °C for 4 days, colorless plate-shaped crystals of 2 were obtained. A direct hydrothermal treatment of the above initial reaction mixture under similar conditions can also afford crystals of 2, but the average crystal size is somewhat smaller. The phase purity was confirmed by XRD measurement (Figure S2 in the ). Anal. Calc. for C19H17N2O4P1Cd1 (M r = 480.72): C 47.47, H 3.56, N 5.83%. Found: C 47.41, H 3.66, N 5.78%. The solid-state luminescent spectra of 1–3 were investigated at room temperature (Figure ). The free 2-carboxyethyl­(phenyl)­phosphinate ligand shows only a fluorescent emission band at λmax = 293 nm under 225 nm excitation. The 4,4′-bipyridine ligand displays a broad fluorescent emission band at λmax = 423 nm upon excitation at 345 nm. Upon complexion of the L2– ligand and 4,4′-bipyridine ligand with the Cd2+ ions, complex 1 displays a fluorescent emission band at λmax = 429 nm (λex = 379 nm), and compound 2 displays a fluorescent emission band at λmax = 369, 388 nm (λex = 336 nm), while compound 3 displays a fluorescent emission band at λmax = 379 nm (λex= 283 nm). These emission bands are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) in nature, but rather can be attributed to an intraligand (IL) and ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT) emission state, which is similar to our previously reported zinc­(II) phosphonate with bipy as a coligand.

Thermogravimetric Analysis

TGA curves of 1 and 3 both exhibit three main steps of weight losses, while that of 2 features two main steps of weight losses (Figure ). For 1 and 3, the first steps of weight loss correspond to the release of 2 and 0.5 H2O, respectively. The observed weight loss for 1 (7.2%) is close to the calculated value (7.0%), which starts at 90 °C and is complete at 156 °C, and the observed weight loss for 3 (2.2%) is equal to the calculated value (2.2%), which starts at 40 °C and is complete at 95 °C. The subsequent weight losses of 1 and 3 start at 172 and 273 °C, respectively, corresponding to the decomposition of the organic ligands. TGA curve of 2 shows that it is stable up to 167 °C, whereupon the decomposition of the organic ligand occurs. By and large, we can deduce that the framework of 3 is more stable than those of 1 and 2.
